From mredd at cores.utah.edu  Tue Jan  6 15:07:24 2015
From: mredd at cores.utah.edu (Michael Redd)
Date: Tue, 6 Jan 2015 21:07:24 +0000
Subject: [OpenSPIM] two colors with Openspim plugin
Message-ID: <D0D19C9B.21995%mredd@cores.utah.edu>

I have set up an Openspim microscope with a 488nm line and would like to add another laser. What is puzzling me is whether the Openspim plugin is capable of capturing two channels? I have added a 543nm gas laser and a shutter, but have been unable to set up channels in Openspim as one can easily do in micromanager. I can collect red and green channels in micromanager but cannot control the twister motor. Can anyone advise me?

From stuyvenberg at wisc.edu  Wed Jan  7 02:03:40 2015
From: stuyvenberg at wisc.edu (Luke Stuyvenberg)
Date: Wed, 07 Jan 2015 01:03:40 -0700
Subject: [OpenSPIM] Fwd: A new question about our Light Sheet
In-Reply-To: <E290B56E-C22C-467D-9063-23C2DCEB7D89@gmail.com>
References: <E290B56E-C22C-467D-9063-23C2DCEB7D89@gmail.com>
Message-ID: <54ACE85C.7000108@wisc.edu>

Hi Christian,

On 1/6/2015 4:56 AM, Cristian Undurraga wrote:
> Hi Luke,
>
> I?m Cristian Undurraga from Chile, we were talking about our OpenSpim Light Sheet at beginning of the last year.
>
> Some weeks ago (20th Dic) we updated the software but after this we presented problems with the software. The Fiji program didn?t work properly, neither the uManager. We try the update again (22th Dic), Fiji open correctly but now the uManager plugin don`t recognize the devices (Laser, camera and stage control).
>
> We also downloaded again the Fiji package with the last version of OpenSpim but didn`t bring the "stage control" plugin to our Light Sheet .
>
> If you could help us, or other person in OpenSpim who can help us, we would be grateful.
> I send the CoreLog from those days:
I'm afraid I'm no longer active in the development of the OpenSPIM 
platform; I've had to move across the United States for graduate school, 
and I have a very difficult time working remotely while enrolled in 
graduate-level classes. I've forwarded this e-mail onto the OpenSPIM 
mailing list (openspim at openspim.org), where it should reach people much 
more familiar with the current state of the project than I am. (I 
suggest CCing that list in the future as well; they'll be able to 
provide more up-to-date help more quickly than I can.)

That said, here's the problems I see, based on your most recent core log:
- The camera (OrcaFlash) is failing to initialize (line 227): "Error 
code 40 (28 hex)." (Sadly I've no idea what precisely that error code 
means. It may be the memory bug rearing its head again, so perhaps 
limiting Fiji's memory will solve this.)
- The laser (Cobolt) is having an error when the program asks whether or 
not it's turned on (line 339). This leads to a number of errors, since 
the laser is in an invalid state -- for instance on lines 415 and, when 
OpenSPIM is loading, 819. (This second error I've seen before, but I 
don't recall the fix -- I believed it was a bug in the Cobolt device 
adapter at the time.)

As usual, please make sure your Fiji and OpenSPIM are completely 
up-to-date by running the Fiji updater. (I usually run it, restart Fiji, 
then repeat until the updater says Fiji is up-to-date.)

My best suggestion for an immediate fix would be to re-make your 
configuration file according to the process on our wiki. (It may help to 
select 'none' as the configuration file when Micro-Manager is opening.) 
It's possible that device adapter names or their property names have 
changed, so doing this might create a working configuration file.

However, as I understand it, some significant development has been 
happening on OpenSPIM recently to improve its relationship to 
Micro-Manager (which will probably lead to 64-bit OpenSPIM, among other 
benefits!). Not all the changes may be in the updater; it's also 
possible the installation process has changed entirely. Hopefully the 
mailing list can offer some advice on this point.

Hope this helps,
Luke Stuyvenberg

From harz at biz.uni-muenchen.de  Mon Jan 12 08:25:37 2015
From: harz at biz.uni-muenchen.de (Hartmann Harz)
Date: Mon, 12 Jan 2015 15:25:37 +0100
Subject: [OpenSPIM] twister motor belt slipping
In-Reply-To: <D0936C31.1AC62%mredd@cores.utah.edu>
References: <D0922475.1AC48%mredd@cores.utah.edu>
	<546CFB85.2090501@biz.uni-muenchen.de>
	<D0936C31.1AC62%mredd@cores.utah.edu>
Message-ID: <54B3D961.4070303@biz.uni-muenchen.de>

Hi Michael,
sorry for my delayed answer, your e-mail was filtered out.

However, I asked the head of our workshop and he toled me that he 
mounted a 6001 bearing (the number means outer diameter 28 mm, inner 
diameter 12 mm hight 8 mm) into our setup. This bearing has no sealing 
and no grease and is made of brass (balls, cage). He told me that such 
bearings are available as a standard for example from SKF oder FAG. For 
the exact number you should ask your local dealer because there are 
hundreds of different bearings available.

The belt was customized from bulk stock. They cutted of a piece of 
appropriate length and glued the cutted edges together with sperglue. I 
was surprised to see this, but it works fine.

Best

Hartmann




On 20.11.2014 18:02, Michael Redd wrote:
> Thank you for the informative reply. I would be much obliged if you 
> would provide me the part information on the replacement bearings and 
> belt.
>
> From: Hartmann Harz <harz at biz.uni-muenchen.de 
> <mailto:harz at biz.uni-muenchen.de>>
> Date: Wednesday, November 19, 2014 2:20 PM
> To: Michael Redd <mredd at cores.utah.edu <mailto:mredd at cores.utah.edu>>, 
> "openspim at openspim.org <mailto:openspim at openspim.org>" 
> <openspim at openspim.org <mailto:openspim at openspim.org>>
> Cc: "edgar.escobar.nieto at ipt.fraunhofer.de 
> <mailto:edgar.escobar.nieto at ipt.fraunhofer.de>" 
> <edgar.escobar.nieto at ipt.fraunhofer.de 
> <mailto:edgar.escobar.nieto at ipt.fraunhofer.de>>
> Subject: Re: [OpenSPIM] twister motor belt slipping
>
> Dear Michael,
> in the bginning I also had the problem of belt slipping. At least I 
> was believing that the belt slips. Later I learned that the belt 
> tesion was to high and the bearing was hard-steering. This results 
> during the operation of the twister stepping motor in a loss of steps. 
> Loss of steps or slipping has the same effect, the twister does not 
> turn to the expected angle. We solved this issue by exchanging the 
> bearing with a smooth running one and by a LONGER belt producing lower 
> tension and thereby lower friction in the bearings of the motor and 
> the sample holder.
>
> I don't know if this helps to solve your problem but eventually this 
> could help others. At least here in Munich it worked.
>
> Best regards
>
> Hartmann
>
> -- 
> Dr. H. Harz
> Ludwig-Maximilians-Universit?t M?nchen
> Biozentrum
> AG Prof. Leonhardt
> Raum B02.059
> Gro?haderner Stra?e 2
> 82152 Martinsried
> Germany
> Phone: +49(89)2180-74 259
> Fax: +49(89)218099-74 236
> Mail:harz at biz.uni-muenchen.de
>
>

>> mentioned.  I have seen the toothed belt used by Edgar's group in 
>> Aachen and would be much obliged if he described this in more detail 
>> so I could copy it.

From gabriel.jones at florey.edu.au  Thu Jan 15 08:10:13 2015
From: gabriel.jones at florey.edu.au (Gabriel Davis Jones)
Date: Thu, 15 Jan 2015 14:10:13 +0000
Subject: [OpenSPIM] Best practices for using a different camera?
Message-ID: <005022868505164C94291D8DD2D8EBAA7415076C@000S-EX-MBX-QS4.unimelb.edu.au>

Hi All,

We are currently trying to use an Andor Neo camera in our OpenSPIM setup instead of the described Hamamatsu.
Is there some "best practices" advice anyone could give regarding how to go about using a different camera in the setup (preferably the Andor Neo) and how to get the FIJI/OpenSPIM package to cooperate with the camera?

Thank you,


Gabriel Davis Jones


Florey Institute for Neuroscience and Mental Health
Laboratory for Ion Channels and Human Diseases
Level 1 Kenneth Myer Building
Genetics Lane on Royal Parade

From guenther at mpi-cbg.de  Fri Jan 16 05:23:15 2015
From: guenther at mpi-cbg.de (=?UTF-8?Q?Ulrik_G=C3=BCnther?=)
Date: 16 Jan 2015 12:23:15 +0100
Subject: [OpenSPIM] Best practices for using a different camera?
In-Reply-To: <005022868505164C94291D8DD2D8EBAA7415076C@000S-EX-MBX-QS4.unimelb.edu.au>
References: <005022868505164C94291D8DD2D8EBAA7415076C@000S-EX-MBX-QS4.unimelb.edu.au>
Message-ID: <440928CF-DBFD-4F5C-BECD-2ADBF60CEF68@mpi-cbg.de>

  Hello Gabriel,


we are also using Andor Neo cameras and they work pretty great.?


Currently, we are refactoring the OpenSPIM plugin, so it can be used with a normal installation of Fiji and MicroManager, so our special package is not needed anymore. I have a recent nightly build available, based on MicroManager 1.4.18, which you can find at?https://idisk-srv1.mpi-cbg.de/~gunther/OpenSPIM/mFiji.zip
?The corresponding OpenSPIM plugin is available at?https://idisk-srv1.mpi-cbg.de/~gunther/OpenSPIM/SPIMacquisition.jar
?and has to be put into the mmplugins/ directory. This version also works on 64bit machines.


With this version, you can just create your setup as usual, just select the Andor SDK3 as camera.


Please let me know if that worked for you :-)


cheers,


ulrik

From m.pawlowska at nencki.gov.pl  Fri Jan 16 05:33:38 2015
From: m.pawlowska at nencki.gov.pl (=?utf-8?B?TW9uaWthIFBhd8WCb3dza2E=?=)
Date: Fri, 16 Jan 2015 12:33:38 +0100
Subject: [OpenSPIM] OpenSPIM app 64bit and other issues
Message-ID: <op.xsjzqcn1ahhlbl@pc511-7cad.ibd>

Hi all,

I am new here, so first of all - big thanks to everybody for taking time
to help!

Now, to the topic. Are there any news regarding a possible 64bit version  
of the package? Or alternatively, an instruction that one can follow to  
install/build a 64bit version on one's own machine? For example by adding  
the 64bit micro-manager .dll libraries manually?

In the end I got the package running by using the ImageJ_win32 in  
compatibility mode. However, the solution Luke proposed in one of his  
emails - to put a java folder in the openspim.app folder - doesn't work  
for me and I was forced to change the JAVA_HOME option to use the 32bit  
java globally. Now I'm concerned that it will mess up other things. Do you  
have any experience with that?

Best regards,

From guenther at mpi-cbg.de  Fri Jan 16 05:42:15 2015
From: guenther at mpi-cbg.de (=?UTF-8?Q?Ulrik_G=C3=BCnther?=)
Date: 16 Jan 2015 12:42:15 +0100
Subject: [OpenSPIM] OpenSPIM app 64bit and other issues
In-Reply-To: <op.xsjzqcn1ahhlbl@pc511-7cad.ibd>
References: <op.xsjzqcn1ahhlbl@pc511-7cad.ibd>
Message-ID: <25B9D7CD-486B-45E0-98FD-D5DE6518B2D7@mpi-cbg.de>

  Hello Monika,


we?re currently working on making OpenSPIM into a simple MicroManager plugin so the whole custom MicroManager package is not needed anymore.?
This will also solve your 64bit troubles. For the moment, I can provide you with a 64bit build based on MicroManager 1.4.18, which you can find at?https://idisk-srv1.mpi-cbg.de/~gunther/OpenSPIM/mFiji.zip



You?ll also need the OpenSPIM plugin, which you can find at?https://idisk-srv1.mpi-cbg.de/~gunther/OpenSPIM/SPIMacquisition.jar
?- this has to be put in mmplugins/
Please also make sure you have the 1.8 version of the Java JRE installed.


Let me know if that worked for you :-)


cheers,


ulrik

CriticalError: plugins/Volume_Viewer-2.01.1-SNAPSHOT.jar
Multiple locally-modified versions of  
plugins/Volume_Viewer-2.01.1-SNAPSHOT.jar exist:  
C:\Users\MPAWLO~1\DOWNLO~1\mFiji\mFiji\plugins\Volume_Viewer.jar

From mredd at cores.utah.edu  Fri Jan 16 17:13:27 2015
From: mredd at cores.utah.edu (Michael Redd)
Date: Fri, 16 Jan 2015 23:13:27 +0000
Subject: [OpenSPIM] OpenSpim
In-Reply-To: <CABA5pkxKcnC0c=jZVUfF14__YEgv0ce01NuKVM8jMUWa6qAoSw@mail.gmail.com>
References: <CABA5pkxKcnC0c=jZVUfF14__YEgv0ce01NuKVM8jMUWa6qAoSw@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <D0DEE70D.21F06%mredd@cores.utah.edu>

Hi Hugo,
I have been using the multidimensional acquisition in MM as well for acquisition of multiple channels and found that it works well with the Picard twister, but I have to adjust the position of the twister motor with the openspim acquistion plugin. Maybe this was obvious to everyone else.  My Orca ER appears to be synced with my Stradus laser and my Vincent shutter (543 HeNe laser). I am sorry that  cannot advise you  concerning your timing problem.

Good luck
mike

From: Hugo S?derlund <hugo.soderlund at gmail.com<mailto:hugo.soderlund at gmail.com>>
Date: Friday, January 16, 2015 7:30 AM
To: Michael Redd <michael.redd at hci.utah.edu<mailto:michael.redd at hci.utah.edu>>
Subject: OpenSpim
Resent-From: Michael Redd <michael.redd at hci.utah.edu<mailto:michael.redd at hci.utah.edu>>

Hi Michael,

I saw your message on the OpenSpim website about using two colors. We want to do the same thing. We have 488, 405 and 561 nm lasers installed and we are trying to use the multidimensional acquisition in MM (since there is no multi channel acquisition in OpenSpim) in order to acquire at least two channels for each z-stack. Unfortunately I cannot help you with your problem since we are not using the twister, only stepping in z-direction. But I was wondering if you have some advice for us.. We have noticed that the MultiDimensional acquisition is out of sync for the camera and the lasers, did you connect the camera with the lasers using TTL connection? If so, did you use the camera as master or slave in your connection? Does it require an arduino curcuit or similar?

Many questions, but any help would be very much appreciated. Thank you for your time.

Kind regards,

Hugo

From johannes.schindelin at gmx.de  Sat Jan 17 11:33:11 2015
From: johannes.schindelin at gmx.de (Johannes Schindelin)
Date: Sat, 17 Jan 2015 18:33:11 +0100
Subject: [OpenSPIM] rotational calibration
In-Reply-To: <D0DEEA30.21F3C%mredd@cores.utah.edu>
References: <D0DEEA30.21F3C%mredd@cores.utah.edu>
Message-ID: <03f116cdf4a4afe7dcc9e65e57088902@www.dscho.org>

Hi Michael,

On 2015-01-17 00:17, Michael Redd wrote:
> I am struggling with the rotational calibration tool. It doesn't
> appear to function at all on my machine (Windows 7 32bit). After
> calibrating pixel size, I can open up the rotational calibration
> window, but that is as far as I get. Pushing the"obtain next" button
> doesn't appear to do anything. Futhermore, I  can't find good
> instructions on  how to rotationally calibrate the Openspim. Any
> advice would be welcome.

Unfortunately, this is a part of the OpenSPIM software that was affected 
by a backwards-incompatible update in one of the libraries shipped with 
Fiji. I hope to find some time on Monday to prepare an updated OpenSPIM 
plugin that copes with that change, but in the meantime you could maybe 
verify that my suspicion is correct, by following the steps described in 
http://fiji.sc/Command-Line_Debugging to obtain the console output (if I 
am right, there should be a ClassNotFound or MethodNotFound exception in 
the log).

Ciao,
Johannes


From johannes.schindelin at gmx.de  Sat Jan 17 11:40:46 2015
From: johannes.schindelin at gmx.de (Johannes Schindelin)
Date: Sat, 17 Jan 2015 18:40:46 +0100
Subject: [OpenSPIM] two colors with Openspim plugin
In-Reply-To: <D0D19C9B.21995%mredd@cores.utah.edu>
References: <D0D19C9B.21995%mredd@cores.utah.edu>
Message-ID: <44fbb519ed4085d45e2867a5f90cabad@www.dscho.org>

Hi Michael,

On 2015-01-06 22:07, Michael Redd wrote:
> I have set up an Openspim microscope with a 488nm line and would like
> to add another laser. What is puzzling me is whether the Openspim
> plugin is capable of capturing two channels? I have added a 543nm gas
> laser and a shutter, but have been unable to set up channels in
> Openspim as one can easily do in micromanager. I can collect red and
> green channels in micromanager but cannot control the twister motor.
> Can anyone advise me?

You are correct: it should not be a big problem in the OpenSPIM software 
because Micro-Manager already supports multiple channels.

Having said that, it is an undertaking that requires Java programming 
skills and the OpenSPIM project has yet to attract more scientists with 
such skills to become stronger. Do you have such skills, or access to 
such a person? If so, I would try to find the time to identify the 
locations in the code that need changes.

Ciao,
Johannes

Hi Johannes and Michael, 

We're putting together a five line OpenSPIM and one of my goals was to get multichannel/multi laser control in the OpenSPIM plugin.  I have a reasonable amount of Java experience-mostly imagej plugins.  I was planning on tackle this in the coming weeks as more parts for our microscope arrive.  I need to look under the hood of micromanager as well and look at the OpenSPIM source.  If only time there was more time.  In any event I'd be happy to start working on this-or, I'm going to have to start working  on it soon!

Cheers,

Seth

From johannes.schindelin at gmx.de  Sun Jan 18 08:23:48 2015
From: johannes.schindelin at gmx.de (Johannes Schindelin)
Date: Sun, 18 Jan 2015 15:23:48 +0100
Subject: [OpenSPIM] two colors with Openspim plugin
In-Reply-To: <0154B08B-03D0-4128-9DE1-AEC388C1715F@iu.edu>
References: <D0D19C9B.21995%mredd@cores.utah.edu>,
	<44fbb519ed4085d45e2867a5f90cabad@www.dscho.org>
	<0154B08B-03D0-4128-9DE1-AEC388C1715F@iu.edu>
Message-ID: <00ab67f3aeaa18431aeeea12044681ec@www.dscho.org>

Hi Seth,

On 2015-01-17 19:48, Winfree, Seth wrote:

> We're putting together a five line OpenSPIM and one of my goals was to
> get multichannel/multi laser control in the OpenSPIM plugin.  I have a
> reasonable amount of Java experience-mostly imagej plugins.  I was
> planning on tackle this in the coming weeks as more parts for our
> microscope arrive.  I need to look under the hood of micromanager as
> well and look at the OpenSPIM source.  If only time there was more
> time.  In any event I'd be happy to start working on this-or, I'm
> going to have to start working  on it soon!

This is awesome news. Please keep in mind that I started migrating the 
OpenSPIM plugin for Micro-Manager into its own repository: 
https://github.com/openspim/SPIMAcquisition

It is now organized as a Maven project which means that you can simply 
import into your development environment of choice.

My original plan (with which I tasked a student who was working on the 
software at that time) was to get the plugin included in Micro-Manager 
proper, but unfortunately the plugin has already way too many 
dependencies that are only available in Fiji and not in Micro-Manager 
(and it would be unreasonable to ask the Micro-Manager developers to 
include them just for OpenSPIM).


And yes, if time was less of a concern, then we would already have

- a split between the parts of OpenSPIM that truly need libraries 
shipped only with Fiji and the parts that only need what Micro-Manager 
provides out of the box

- a way to test inside Eclipse, including mock devices including a 
twister

- regression tests

It would be really nice to have, but I simply do not have the time to 
make any of the above a reality.

All the better that you need to work at least on some part of the 
software :-) Please feel more than welcome to ask any question you have 
about the OpenSPIM or Micro-Manager source code; I will try to address 
as many as possible, after all: the more we work together and help each 
other, the better the OpenSPIM project will benefit every one of us.

Ciao,
Johannes


From guenther at mpi-cbg.de  Sun Jan 18 10:27:00 2015
From: guenther at mpi-cbg.de (=?UTF-8?Q?Ulrik_G=C3=BCnther?=)
Date: 18 Jan 2015 17:27:00 +0100
Subject: [OpenSPIM] two colors with Openspim plugin
In-Reply-To: <00ab67f3aeaa18431aeeea12044681ec@www.dscho.org>

From beekayspim at gmail.com  Mon Jan 19 22:57:29 2015
From: beekayspim at gmail.com (Balki K)
Date: Tue, 20 Jan 2015 12:57:29 +0800
Subject: [OpenSPIM] SCAPE and SPIM
Message-ID: <CAG6WU3UbGug8Ww9Wpjaa3Stn5aedGHDxvNWnK78qZPPY6RRY4g@mail.gmail.com>

Dear All,

I am a new entrant into SPIM as well this forum.

I have been asked to explore building a mSPIM system for our institute. But
yesterday there was an update on a new type of system called SCAPE.

Please have a look at the online version of the publication in Nature
Photonics from Hillman's group in Columbia University, NY.

I have a clear understanding of SPIM system. But SCAPE is new to me. Is
there someone who is familiar with the two different systems that can
explain the pros & cons o SCAPE system?

Best Regards,
Balki
-------------- next part --------------
An HTML attachment was scrubbed...
URL: <http://openspim.org/pipermail/openspim/attachments/20150120/7ff3e917/attachment.html>

From johannes.schindelin at gmx.de  Tue Jan 20 01:50:20 2015
From: johannes.schindelin at gmx.de (Johannes Schindelin)
Date: Tue, 20 Jan 2015 08:50:20 +0100
Subject: [OpenSPIM] SCAPE and SPIM
In-Reply-To: <CAG6WU3UbGug8Ww9Wpjaa3Stn5aedGHDxvNWnK78qZPPY6RRY4g@mail.gmail.com>
References: <CAG6WU3UbGug8Ww9Wpjaa3Stn5aedGHDxvNWnK78qZPPY6RRY4g@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <0d2afa3c93b0c39744d8af536aa8298b@www.dscho.org>

Hi Balki,

On 2015-01-20 05:57, Balki K wrote:

> I am a new entrant into SPIM as well this forum.

Welcome! ;-)

> I have been asked to explore building a mSPIM system for our institute. 
> But
> yesterday there was an update on a new type of system called SCAPE.
> 
> Please have a look at the online version of the publication in Nature
> Photonics from Hillman's group in Columbia University, NY.

We are all busy, so it is a good practice to include a link if you 
already have one handy. I looked it up and I *think* you refer to this 
one?

http://www.nature.com/nphoton/journal/vaop/ncurrent/full/nphoton.2014.323.html

Unfortunately, I am not at a computer which can access the full text 
(and even more unfortunate: the authors did not upload preprints to 
arxiv nor bioRxiv) and you will understand that $32 is a bit much just 
to be able to analyze the technique for you ;-)

> I have a clear understanding of SPIM system. But SCAPE is new to me. Is
> there someone who is familiar with the two different systems that can
> explain the pros & cons o SCAPE system?

Please keep in mind that I bring the software engineering expertise to 
the OpenSPIM project in our lab, not the optics expertise (you probably 
have much more knowledge of optics, given that you are tasked to build a 
microscope). And please keep in mind that I form the following 
understanding only from reading the abstract of the article, supported 
only by the figure at 
http://www.nature.com/nphoton/journal/vaop/ncurrent/fig_tab/nphoton.2014.323_F1.html.

With those caveats in mind, my interpretation is that their microscope 
uses a scanning mirror (or cantilever) to move the light sheet through 
the specimen, and that the light sheet is not perpendicular to the 
acquisition axis but at an oblique angle.

The OpenSPIM setup we published uses a stage to move the specimen 
instead of the light sheet (which means that the optical sections are 
parallel, unlike the sections obtained by rotating the light sheet with 
a cantilever ? even if they are *almost* parallel in practice). Further, 
in the OpenSPIM setup, the images have uniform pixel spacings because 
the light sheet is perpendicular to the acquisition axis, while the 
pixel spacings in images acquired by the SCAPE microscope differ not 
only depending on the current angle of the light sheet but also on the 
exact coordinate on the image plane.

The major difference, therefore, appears that the SCAPE microscope can 
be much faster (because it moves the light sheet much faster), at the 
expense of requiring a sophisticated reconstruction algorithm because of 
the non-uniform pixel spacings (read: point spread functions).

It would be really cool if you could adapt the OpenSPIM setup to support 
SCAPE microscopy; You should make sure that you have access to a gifted 
mathematician with intermediate programming skills to implement the 
image reconstruction (read: the all-too-common half-hearted Matlab 
snippet won't do at all).

Looking forward to your progress!
Johannes

Johannes

From: Ulrik G?nther [guenther at mpi-cbg.de]
Sent: 16 January 2015 22:23
To: Gabriel Davis Jones
Cc: openspim at openspim.org
Subject: Re: [OpenSPIM] Best practices for using a different camera?

Hello Gabriel,

we are also using Andor Neo cameras and they work pretty great.

Currently, we are refactoring the OpenSPIM plugin, so it can be used with a normal installation of Fiji and MicroManager, so our special package is not needed anymore. I have a recent nightly build available, based on MicroManager 1.4.18, which you can find at https://idisk-srv1.mpi-cbg.de/~gunther/OpenSPIM/mFiji.zip The corresponding OpenSPIM plugin is available at https://idisk-srv1.mpi-cbg.de/~gunther/OpenSPIM/SPIMacquisition.jar and has to be put into the mmplugins/ directory. This version also works on 64bit machines.

With this version, you can just create your setup as usual, just select the Andor SDK3 as camera.

Please let me know if that worked for you :-)

cheers,

ulrik


-
Ulrik G?nther, Dipl.-Phys.
PhD Student
MOSAIC Group & Tomancak Lab, Center of Systems Biology Dresden
Max Planck Institute of Molecular Cell Biology and Genetics
Pfotenhauerstr. 108, D-01307 Dresden, Germany

E-Mail: guenther at mpi-cbg.de

On Jan 15, 2015, at 3:10 PM, Gabriel Davis Jones <gabriel.jones at florey.edu.au> wrote:

Hi All,

We are currently trying to use an Andor Neo camera in our OpenSPIM setup instead of the described Hamamatsu.
Is there some "best practices" advice anyone could give regarding how to go about using a different camera in the setup (preferably the Andor Neo) and how to get the FIJI/OpenSPIM package to cooperate with the camera?

Thank you,


Gabriel Davis Jones


Florey Institute for Neuroscience and Mental Health
Laboratory for Ion Channels and Human Diseases
Level 1 Kenneth Myer Building
Genetics Lane on Royal Parade

From gabriel.jones at florey.edu.au  Thu Jan 22 01:38:28 2015
From: gabriel.jones at florey.edu.au (Gabriel Davis Jones)
Date: Thu, 22 Jan 2015 07:38:28 +0000
Subject: [OpenSPIM] Best practices for using a different camera?
In-Reply-To: <440928CF-DBFD-4F5C-BECD-2ADBF60CEF68@mpi-cbg.de>
References: <005022868505164C94291D8DD2D8EBAA7415076C@000S-EX-MBX-QS4.unimelb.edu.au>,
	<440928CF-DBFD-4F5C-BECD-2ADBF60CEF68@mpi-cbg.de>
Message-ID: <005022868505164C94291D8DD2D8EBAA7415610D@000S-EX-MBX-QS4.unimelb.edu.au>

Hi All,

The issue was solved by reinstalling the drivers to the mFiji package using the following Andor package: http://www.andor.com/ftp/14544/AndorDriverPack3Setup-3.7.30010.0.ziphttp://www.andor.com/ftp/14544/AndorDriverPack3Setup-3.7.30010.0.zip
When prompted for the install location, just change it to the mFiji folder.

Thanks Ulrik for all the help!


Kind regards,

Gabriel Davis Jones

Laboratory for Ion Channels and Human Diseases
Level 1 Kenneth Myer Building
Genetics Lane on Royal Parade
The University of Melbourne  Vic  3010

From m.pawlowska at nencki.gov.pl  Thu Jan 22 04:54:42 2015
From: m.pawlowska at nencki.gov.pl (=?utf-8?B?TW9uaWthIFBhd8WCb3dza2E=?=)
Date: Thu, 22 Jan 2015 11:54:42 +0100
Subject: [OpenSPIM] Picard hi-res stage
Message-ID: <op.xsu1xghwahhlbl@pc511-7cad.ibd>

Hi,

thanks to the help of Ulrik I was able to install and run the OpenSPIM  
plugin in my lab. When testing the Picard stage, I noticed following  
issues:

-integer range issue: I have bought the new Hi-Res Picard stage which can  
do 45 000 steps. However, in the OpenSPIM plugin I can only do 32 767  
steps (16bit integer range if I'm not wrong)

-display issue: the GUI of the plugin, I mean the window with the sliders  
for the stage, only shows range up to 9000 um, but the new Hi-res stage  
can do 12000 um. How can this be changed?

I think the first issue is already in the MManager driver for the Picard,  
the second in the java OpenSPIM plugin. Does somebody have the solution  
already or could gave me a hint what to do?

Best regards,

-- 
Monika Paw?owska
Nencki Institute
Laboratory of Neurobiology
3, Pasteur Street
02-093 Warsaw, Poland

From: gabriel.jones at florey.edu.au (Gabriel Davis Jones)
Date: Thu, 22 Jan 2015 12:12:17 +0000
Subject: [OpenSPIM] Best practices for using a different camera?
In-Reply-To: <BAE91F68-8951-4EEE-8AD3-5F1883073BEC@mpi-cbg.de>

Hi All,

The issue was solved by reinstalling the drivers to the mFiji package using the following Andor package: http://www.andor.com/ftp/14544/AndorDriverPack3Setup-3.7.30010.0.ziphttp://www.andor.com/ftp/14544/AndorDriverPack3Setup-3.7.30010.0.zip
When prompted for the install location, just change it to the mFiji folder.

From:Ulrik G?nther [guenther at mpi-cbg.de]
Sent:16 January 2015 22:23
To:Gabriel Davis Jones
Cc:openspim at openspim.org
Subject:Re: [OpenSPIM] Best practices for using a different camera?

Hello Gabriel,

we are also using Andor Neo cameras and they work pretty great.

Currently, we are refactoring the OpenSPIM plugin, so it can be used with a normal installation of Fiji and MicroManager, so our special package is not needed anymore. I have a recent nightly build available, based on MicroManager 1.4.18, which you can find at https://idisk-srv1.mpi-cbg.de/~gunther/OpenSPIM/mFiji.zip The corresponding OpenSPIM plugin is available at https://idisk-srv1.mpi-cbg.de/~gunther/OpenSPIM/SPIMacquisition.jar and has to be put into the mmplugins/ directory. This version also works on 64bit machines.

With this version, you can just create your setup as usual, just select the Andor SDK3 as camera.

Please let me know if that worked for you :-)

cheers,

ulrik


?
Ulrik G?nther, Dipl.-Phys.
PhD Student
MOSAIC Group & Tomancak Lab, Center of Systems Biology Dresden
Max Planck Institute of Molecular Cell Biology and Genetics
Pfotenhauerstr. 108, D-01307 Dresden, Germany

E-Mail: guenther at mpi-cbg.de

Hi All,

We are currently trying to use an Andor Neo camera in our OpenSPIM setup instead of the described Hamamatsu.
Is there some "best practices" advice anyone could give regarding how to go about using a different camera in the setup (preferably the Andor Neo) and how to get the FIJI/OpenSPIM package to cooperate with the camera?

> for the stage, only shows range up to 9000 um, but the new Hi-res stage?
> can do 12000 um. How can this be changed?
> This is not a display issue but related to the fact above - the OpenSPIM plugin does not know about it :)

Hi Ulrik,

On 2015-01-22 14:35, Ulrik G?nther wrote:

> * can we use Travis CI or something to check whether the plugin
> builds/works with ?M and Fiji nightlies?

We could (for lurkers, Ulrik speaks about a server dedicated to building 
and testing the software, say, every night). There is a Jenkins CI at 
http://jenkins.imagej.net/ that Fiji and ImageJ use. We could easily set 
something up there.

But we do not have any regression tests; therefore, the usefulness of 
such a continuous integration is not yet large enough to merit the huge 
amount of work to get the continuous integration up and running *and* to 
keep it running.

> * I?d also integrate support for the high precision stage Monika is
> using (see her other mail on the list)

Sure! I'll be glad to review and merge any Pull Request you throw my 
way.

Ciao,
Johannes

References: <005022868505164C94291D8DD2D8EBAA7415076C@000S-EX-MBX-QS4.unimelb.edu.au>
	<440928CF-DBFD-4F5C-BECD-2ADBF60CEF68@mpi-cbg.de>
	<005022868505164C94291D8DD2D8EBAA7415610D@000S-EX-MBX-QS4.unimelb.edu.au>
	<BAE91F68-8951-4EEE-8AD3-5F1883073BEC@mpi-cbg.de>
	<e37cf2111dc6e548238b24d17ba2a83f@www.dscho.org>
	<DCA1BC2E-7009-4DB5-87D3-B4569DA6C5F2@mpi-cbg.de>
	<d84c819e1b8e739cdc5c214808ee2542@www.dscho.org>
	<342AF7E9-74E5-41C5-B02F-1F2C51311211@mpi-cbg.de>
Message-ID: <bfe1ba9568144e6bc5fba274539d41bc@www.dscho.org>

Hi Ulrik,

On 2015-01-22 14:57, Ulrik G?nther wrote:

>> On Jan 22, 2015, at 2:51 PM, Johannes Schindelin 
>> <johannes.schindelin at gmx.de> wrote:
>> 
>> We could (for lurkers, Ulrik speaks about a server dedicated to 
>> building?
>> and testing the software, say, every night). There is a Jenkins CI at?
>> http://jenkins.imagej.net/ that Fiji and ImageJ use. We could easily 
>> set?
>> something up there.
>> >
>> 
>> But we do not have any regression tests; therefore, the usefulness of?
>> such a continuous integration is not yet large enough to merit the 
>> huge?
>> amount of work to get the continuous integration up and running *and* 
>> to?
>> keep it running.
>> 
> 
> Well, until we have actual tests we could at least see whether it
> builds against the latest MicroManager, that?d be helpful to spot
> problems early on. For testing we could later add tests.

Sure. On the other hand, what we *really* need to test against is the 
user installation as per the update site. And that requires regression 
tests, otherwise we think all is right when it might well be thoroughly 
broken.

> I haven?t used Jenkins too deeply so far, but the setup of a
> Maven build with Travis is quite easy.

I know that. The same is true for Maven projects in Jenkins: New job, 
type in the Git URL, build step "Maven", done.

So why do I say it is complicated?

Because we depend on stuff that is not available via Maven repositories. 
And worse, that stuff that is on Maven repositories is not necessarily 
what is present on the OpenSPIM update site. And all that needs to be 
cobbled together and... yep, you guessed it: regression-tested.

Ciao,
Johannes


From m.pawlowska at nencki.gov.pl  Thu Jan 22 09:50:27 2015
From: m.pawlowska at nencki.gov.pl (=?utf-8?B?TW9uaWthIFBhd8WCb3dza2E=?=)
Date: Thu, 22 Jan 2015 16:50:27 +0100
Subject: [OpenSPIM] Picard hi-res stage
In-Reply-To: <ffd76763073d2d2d8b5847148e800080@www.dscho.org>
References: <op.xsu1xghwahhlbl@pc511-7cad.ibd>
	<0E8CB76F-3207-4E84-AAA3-C7768D44FF93@mpi-cbg.de>
	<ffd76763073d2d2d8b5847148e800080@www.dscho.org>
Message-ID: <op.xsvfmdepahhlbl@pc511-7cad.ibd>

Hi Ulrik & Johannes,

I hope this is the screenshot you need. Not much in it though.

What I meant about two separate issues is that there is on one hand the  
32767 limit and on the other - the value 9000 which is hard-coded in  
several places as Johannes noted. (My programming skills are rusty these  
days, but from my undergrad times I remember that hard-coding constants  
into random places in code is not nice. :) )

Regards,
Monika

From beekayspim at gmail.com  Fri Jan 23 03:08:26 2015
From: beekayspim at gmail.com (Balki K)
Date: Fri, 23 Jan 2015 17:08:26 +0800
Subject: [OpenSPIM] SCAPE
Message-ID: <CAG6WU3Wvnc3c1yFatO1NCrdMeWOah-N=Q58n+PTh3PSrzsQihA@mail.gmail.com>

Hi Johannes,

I am thinking in the direction Johannes suggested - adapt OpenSPIM to
include SCAPE.

I still have a question:

You were saying that it requires a sophisticated reconstruction algorithm
because of
the non-uniform pixel spacings.

In the article (Page 6 - SCAPE image analyisis and visualization) the
authors say that

"Three-dimensional volume renderings were generated using volren modules in
Amira
using custom colourmaps. All data shown are in SCAPE (x??y??z?) image space
(Fig. 1b).

The SCAPE data shown in Fig. 2e, Supplementary Fig. 7 and Supplementary
Movie 2
were corrected for the skewing effect of the oblique light sheet by
shifting each depth
plane laterally by a constant, linear factor....... ".

I am not familiar with Amira (and Volren modules in that). But, is it so
straightforward as stated
OR
involves a rigorous geometrical and computational work?

If the authors of the article are seeing this, please help us understand!

Best regards,
Balki



Hi Balki,

On 2015-01-20 05:57, Balki K wrote:

> I am a new entrant into SPIM as well this forum.

Welcome! ;-)

> I have been asked to explore building a mSPIM system for our institute.
> But
> yesterday there was an update on a new type of system called SCAPE.
>
> Please have a look at the online version of the publication in Nature
> Photonics from Hillman's group in Columbia University, NY.

We are all busy, so it is a good practice to include a link if you
already have one handy. I looked it up and I *think* you refer to this
one?

http://www.nature.com/nphoton/journal/vaop/ncurrent/full/
nphoton.2014.323.html

Unfortunately, I am not at a computer which can access the full text
(and even more unfortunate: the authors did not upload preprints to
arxiv nor bioRxiv) and you will understand that $32 is a bit much just
to be able to analyze the technique for you ;-)

> I have a clear understanding of SPIM system. But SCAPE is new to me. Is
> there someone who is familiar with the two different systems that can
> explain the pros & cons o SCAPE system?

Please keep in mind that I bring the software engineering expertise to
the OpenSPIM project in our lab, not the optics expertise (you probably
have much more knowledge of optics, given that you are tasked to build a
microscope). And please keep in mind that I form the following
understanding only from reading the abstract of the article, supported
only by the figure at
http://www.nature.com/nphoton/journal/vaop/ncurrent/fig_tab/
nphoton.2014.323_F1.html.

With those caveats in mind, my interpretation is that their microscope
uses a scanning mirror (or cantilever) to move the light sheet through
the specimen, and that the light sheet is not perpendicular to the
acquisition axis but at an oblique angle.

The OpenSPIM setup we published uses a stage to move the specimen
instead of the light sheet (which means that the optical sections are
parallel, unlike the sections obtained by rotating the light sheet with
a cantilever ? even if they are *almost* parallel in practice). Further,
in the OpenSPIM setup, the images have uniform pixel spacings because
the light sheet is perpendicular to the acquisition axis, while the
pixel spacings in images acquired by the SCAPE microscope differ not
only depending on the current angle of the light sheet but also on the
exact coordinate on the image plane.

The major difference, therefore, appears that the SCAPE microscope can
be much faster (because it moves the light sheet much faster), at the
expense of requiring a sophisticated reconstruction algorithm because of
the non-uniform pixel spacings (read: point spread functions).

It would be really cool if you could adapt the OpenSPIM setup to support
SCAPE microscopy; You should make sure that you have access to a gifted
mathematician with intermediate programming skills to implement the
image reconstruction (read: the all-too-common half-hearted Matlab
snippet won't do at all).

Looking forward to your progress!
Johannes

An HTML attachment was scrubbed...
URL: <http://openspim.org/pipermail/openspim/attachments/20150123/f3b4f906/attachment.html>

From johannes.schindelin at gmx.de  Fri Jan 23 05:59:43 2015
From: johannes.schindelin at gmx.de (Johannes Schindelin)
Date: Fri, 23 Jan 2015 12:59:43 +0100
Subject: [OpenSPIM] SCAPE
In-Reply-To: <CAG6WU3Wvnc3c1yFatO1NCrdMeWOah-N=Q58n+PTh3PSrzsQihA@mail.gmail.com>
References: <CAG6WU3Wvnc3c1yFatO1NCrdMeWOah-N=Q58n+PTh3PSrzsQihA@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <009c79a8fa5f36a4d0338f7702628e9a@www.dscho.org>

Hi,

On 2015-01-23 10:08, Balki K wrote:

> You were saying that it requires a sophisticated reconstruction 
> algorithm
> because of the non-uniform pixel spacings.


Yes. As you can see from the figure I linked to earlier:

> Please keep in mind that I bring the software engineering expertise to
> the OpenSPIM project in our lab, not the optics expertise (you probably
> have much more knowledge of optics, given that you are tasked to build 
> a
> microscope). And please keep in mind that I form the following
> understanding only from reading the abstract of the article, supported
> only by the figure at
> http://www.nature.com/nphoton/journal/vaop/ncurrent/fig_tab/
> nphoton.2014.323_F1.html.

... you can actually see for yourself how the pixel spacing differs 
between planes (and possibly between the pixels in each plane).

Now, I am not an optical expert, but I assume you are. So you should be 
in a better position to answer the question how the pixel spacings 
(often called "pixel dimensions") differ.

In practice, it might be that the differences are negligible, both 
within and between planes. If that is the case, you do not need that 
"sophisticated algorithm" I referred to. In that case, you would only 
need to compensate for the obliqueness of the planes, i.e. the fact that 
the planes are *not* perpendicular to the axis along which the plane is 
moved. It will require a little bit of coding and you should make sure 
to have some colleague or employee who can do that for you (I would 
probably use the interpolation algorithms of ImgLib2 to reconstruct the 
volume stacks).

As stated above, you should not take my hunches at face value. It is 
really important that you understand the intrinsic properties of the 
acquisition to reconstruct the images in software. I would be interested 
in that analysis, too, so if you would share it with this mailing list, 
that would be really cool.

Ciao,
Johannes


From pitrone at mpi-cbg.de  Fri Jan 23 06:52:43 2015
From: pitrone at mpi-cbg.de (Peter Gabriel Pitrone)
Date: Fri, 23 Jan 2015 13:52:43 +0100

Message-ID: <4F4E9AFE-F041-4C2C-92B1-0FA335AB19BF@mpi-cbg.de>

Hello List,

This conversation on a "sophisticated algorithm" to compute the off-axis oblique illumination got me to thinking about how it could be used with Nikon's 10x/0.3 water dipping lenses. Due to the objectives having only a 30 degree taper off the optical axis, you could cram 6 of them in a circle around a sample. It wouldn't be the best detection objective for really small samples, but I think it would work just fine with zebrafish embryos? Not sure about OPT though.

Any one care to chime in?!

Best Regards,
Pete

From weber at mpi-cbg.de  Fri Jan 23 09:31:08 2015
From: weber at mpi-cbg.de (Michael Weber)
Date: Fri, 23 Jan 2015 16:31:08 +0100
Subject: [OpenSPIM] SCAPE
In-Reply-To: <009c79a8fa5f36a4d0338f7702628e9a@www.dscho.org>
References: <CAG6WU3Wvnc3c1yFatO1NCrdMeWOah-N=Q58n+PTh3PSrzsQihA@mail.gmail.com>
	<009c79a8fa5f36a4d0338f7702628e9a@www.dscho.org>
Message-ID: <7A513BCE-3AA6-4626-8480-C992F408E127@mpi-cbg.de>

Dear all,

Figure 1 might be misleading, as only a subset of the entire system is shown. The full optical path of the SCAPE system can be found in Supplementary Figure 1:
http://www.nature.com/nphoton/journal/vaop/ncurrent/extref/nphoton.2014.323-s1.pdf

This system is very similar to the oblique plane microscopy setup published by Chris Dunsby in 2008: Dunsby, C. Optically sectioned imaging by oblique plane microscopy. Opt Express 16, 20306?20316 (2008).

If you cannot access any of the linked papers, try Dunsby's patent:
https://www.google.de/patents/US8582203

And in there, specifically Figure 4:
https://patentimages.storage.googleapis.com/US8582203B2/US08582203-20131112-D00004.png

As you can see, the oblique plane is correct for by introducing another oblique plane? a clever concept, based on what Tony Wilson demonstrated earlier in his remote focussing microscope. So you don't get oblique planes in your final stack, but the images are skewed. Plus, by sending tilted beams through lenses on multiple positions in the path, you introduce aberrations. Moreover, you cannot use the full aperture of your detection objective, as you need some space to bring in your light sheet. And you need 3 objectives? So I don't agree with the author's statement that the setup is simpler than other light sheet setups. It is true that you don't need the 90 deg access to your sample. However, if you can afford that, I think you are still better off with a setup based on piezo scanning or electrically tunable lenses.

Best,
Michael

Howdy SPIMers,

I?ve spent the morning running our OpenSPIM number crunching machine through its paces and had to recompile the CUDA dll for multi view deconvolution to support our CUDA 6.5 only graphics cards.  It works very well with two Quadro K5200s.  If there is any interest I?d be happy to share-through which ever mechanism is best.

I didn?t change anything in the original source code, just recompiled/updated to support CUDA 6.5.  I?d like to look into taking advantage of the some of the new features in the CUDA Toolkit as of 6.5-for another time.

Cheers,

Seth

References: <AM2PR03MB07076EA850DAE52FCE1B0608DD350@AM2PR03MB0707.eurprd03.prod.outlook.com>
Message-ID: <21f0d9f1c0cab4e7fbf86fd101623475@www.dscho.org>

Hi Dylan,

On 2015-01-26 18:55, Windell, Dylan wrote:

> I am having trouble sending an email which I have attached below to
> the normal mailing address, I have registered on the site under this
> email account so I am not sure what is the problem.

Unfortunately I cannot see the mail. And I could not see any previous 
attempts to subscribe, either, so I allowed myself to subscribe you 
directly.

> After reading the recent post regarding SPIM at x64, I am trying to
> get MM to work on my Windows 7 OS working at 64-bit but thus far I
> have not been able to.

Please provide the full information, including all relevant log files 
that you can find. Even if they do not make sense to you, they might 
help others to help you.

> I have installed my Andor drivers and followed
> the steps to install all the software but despite the new SPIM plugin,
> it does not run at all.

Again, a detailed error report is required to help you. If Micro-Manager 
crashes, or if it shows you an error message, or if another message pops 
up; all of that is crucial information that is required to help you make 
sense of the problem and resolve it.

> In addition, when trying to load my
> configuration the program continues to freeze and crash.

That description is unfortunately not precise enough to identify the 
problem. You probably have a CoreLog in your OpenSPIM.app/CoreLogs/ 
directory that should shed light into the issues.

> I know it is still not yet finished being fixed but I was just
> wandering if there is a temporary fix for this?

Unfortunately, it is not possible with specific information (such as the 
information provided by the CoreLog) to know enough about the problem in 
order to assess any possible fix. Please copy & paste precise error 
messages whenever possible, otherwise write them into a mail as 
faithfully as possible, and attach the relevant (parts of the) CoreLog.

Once you do that, I am confident that you will find the OpenSPIM 
community to be helpful in getting your system to work, hopefully so 
much that you also help others to get their systems to work, too.

Ciao,
Johannes

> Again, a detailed error report is required to help you. If
> Micro-Manager crashes, or if it shows you an error message, or if
> another message pops up; all of that is crucial information that is
> required to help you make sense of the problem and resolve it.
> 
>> In addition, when trying to load my
>> configuration the program continues to freeze and crash.
> 
> That description is unfortunately not precise enough to identify the
> problem. You probably have a CoreLog in your OpenSPIM.app/CoreLogs/
> directory that should shed light into the issues.
> 
>> I know it is still not yet finished being fixed but I was just
>> wandering if there is a temporary fix for this?
> 
> Unfortunately, it is not possible with specific information (such as
> the information provided by the CoreLog) to know enough about the
> problem in order to assess any possible fix. Please copy & paste
> precise error messages whenever possible, otherwise write them into a
> mail as faithfully as possible, and attach the relevant (parts of the)
> CoreLog.
> 
> Once you do that, I am confident that you will find the OpenSPIM
> community to be helpful in getting your system to work, hopefully so
> much that you also help others to get their systems to work, too.
> 
> Ciao,
> Johannes

From gabriel.jones at florey.edu.au  Thu Jan 29 05:12:21 2015
From: gabriel.jones at florey.edu.au (Gabriel Davis Jones)
Date: Thu, 29 Jan 2015 11:12:21 +0000
Subject: [OpenSPIM] Micro-Manager Issue
Message-ID: <005022868505164C94291D8DD2D8EBAA7415E810@000S-EX-MBX-QS4.unimelb.edu.au>

Hi Dylan,


I was experiencing similar issues to you.

What seemed to work for me was installing a slightly older version of the drivers that I got from Andor. Here's the link:

http://www.andor.com/ftp/14544/AndorDriverPack3Setup-3.7.30010.0.ziphttp://www.andor.com/ftp/14544/AndorDriverPack3Setup-3.7.30010.0.zip


Kind regards,

From mredd at cores.utah.edu  Tue Jan  6 15:07:24 2015
From: mredd at cores.utah.edu (Michael Redd)
Date: Tue, 6 Jan 2015 21:07:24 +0000
Subject: [OpenSPIM] two colors with Openspim plugin
Message-ID: <D0D19C9B.21995%mredd@cores.utah.edu>

I have set up an Openspim microscope with a 488nm line and would like to add another laser. What is puzzling me is whether the Openspim plugin is capable of capturing two channels? I have added a 543nm gas laser and a shutter, but have been unable to set up channels in Openspim as one can easily do in micromanager. I can collect red and green channels in micromanager but cannot control the twister motor. Can anyone advise me?

An HTML attachment was scrubbed...

From stuyvenberg at wisc.edu  Wed Jan  7 02:03:40 2015
From: stuyvenberg at wisc.edu (Luke Stuyvenberg)
Date: Wed, 07 Jan 2015 01:03:40 -0700
Subject: [OpenSPIM] Fwd: A new question about our Light Sheet
In-Reply-To: <E290B56E-C22C-467D-9063-23C2DCEB7D89@gmail.com>
References: <E290B56E-C22C-467D-9063-23C2DCEB7D89@gmail.com>
Message-ID: <54ACE85C.7000108@wisc.edu>

Hi Christian,

On 1/6/2015 4:56 AM, Cristian Undurraga wrote:
> Hi Luke,
>
> Im Cristian Undurraga from Chile, we were talking about our OpenSpim Light Sheet at beginning of the last year.
>
> Some weeks ago (20th Dic) we updated the software but after this we presented problems with the software. The Fiji program didnt work properly, neither the uManager. We try the update again (22th Dic), Fiji open correctly but now the uManager plugin don`t recognize the devices (Laser, camera and stage control).
>
> We also downloaded again the Fiji package with the last version of OpenSpim but didn`t bring the "stage control" plugin to our Light Sheet .
>
> If you could help us, or other person in OpenSpim who can help us, we would be grateful.
> I send the CoreLog from those days:
I'm afraid I'm no longer active in the development of the OpenSPIM 
platform; I've had to move across the United States for graduate school, 
and I have a very difficult time working remotely while enrolled in 
graduate-level classes. I've forwarded this e-mail onto the OpenSPIM 
mailing list (openspim at openspim.org), where it should reach people much 
more familiar with the current state of the project than I am. (I 
suggest CCing that list in the future as well; they'll be able to 
provide more up-to-date help more quickly than I can.)

That said, here's the problems I see, based on your most recent core log:
- The camera (OrcaFlash) is failing to initialize (line 227): "Error 
code 40 (28 hex)." (Sadly I've no idea what precisely that error code 
means. It may be the memory bug rearing its head again, so perhaps 
limiting Fiji's memory will solve this.)
- The laser (Cobolt) is having an error when the program asks whether or 
not it's turned on (line 339). This leads to a number of errors, since 
the laser is in an invalid state -- for instance on lines 415 and, when 
OpenSPIM is loading, 819. (This second error I've seen before, but I 
don't recall the fix -- I believed it was a bug in the Cobolt device 
adapter at the time.)

As usual, please make sure your Fiji and OpenSPIM are completely 
up-to-date by running the Fiji updater. (I usually run it, restart Fiji, 
then repeat until the updater says Fiji is up-to-date.)

My best suggestion for an immediate fix would be to re-make your 
configuration file according to the process on our wiki. (It may help to 
select 'none' as the configuration file when Micro-Manager is opening.) 
It's possible that device adapter names or their property names have 
changed, so doing this might create a working configuration file.

However, as I understand it, some significant development has been 
happening on OpenSPIM recently to improve its relationship to 
Micro-Manager (which will probably lead to 64-bit OpenSPIM, among other 
benefits!). Not all the changes may be in the updater; it's also 
possible the installation process has changed entirely. Hopefully the 
mailing list can offer some advice on this point.

Hope this helps,
Luke Stuyvenberg

From harz at biz.uni-muenchen.de  Mon Jan 12 08:25:37 2015
From: harz at biz.uni-muenchen.de (Hartmann Harz)
Date: Mon, 12 Jan 2015 15:25:37 +0100
Subject: [OpenSPIM] twister motor belt slipping
In-Reply-To: <D0936C31.1AC62%mredd@cores.utah.edu>
References: <D0922475.1AC48%mredd@cores.utah.edu>
	<546CFB85.2090501@biz.uni-muenchen.de>
	<D0936C31.1AC62%mredd@cores.utah.edu>
Message-ID: <54B3D961.4070303@biz.uni-muenchen.de>

Hi Michael,
sorry for my delayed answer, your e-mail was filtered out.

However, I asked the head of our workshop and he toled me that he 
mounted a 6001 bearing (the number means outer diameter 28 mm, inner 
diameter 12 mm hight 8 mm) into our setup. This bearing has no sealing 
and no grease and is made of brass (balls, cage). He told me that such 
bearings are available as a standard for example from SKF oder FAG. For 
the exact number you should ask your local dealer because there are 
hundreds of different bearings available.

The belt was customized from bulk stock. They cutted of a piece of 
appropriate length and glued the cutted edges together with sperglue. I 
was surprised to see this, but it works fine.

Best

Hartmann




On 20.11.2014 18:02, Michael Redd wrote:
> Thank you for the informative reply. I would be much obliged if you 
> would provide me the part information on the replacement bearings and 
> belt.
>
> From: Hartmann Harz <harz at biz.uni-muenchen.de 
> <mailto:harz at biz.uni-muenchen.de>>
> Date: Wednesday, November 19, 2014 2:20 PM
> To: Michael Redd <mredd at cores.utah.edu <mailto:mredd at cores.utah.edu>>, 
> "openspim at openspim.org <mailto:openspim at openspim.org>" 
> <openspim at openspim.org <mailto:openspim at openspim.org>>
> Cc: "edgar.escobar.nieto at ipt.fraunhofer.de 
> <mailto:edgar.escobar.nieto at ipt.fraunhofer.de>" 
> <edgar.escobar.nieto at ipt.fraunhofer.de 
> <mailto:edgar.escobar.nieto at ipt.fraunhofer.de>>
> Subject: Re: [OpenSPIM] twister motor belt slipping
>
> Dear Michael,
> in the bginning I also had the problem of belt slipping. At least I 
> was believing that the belt slips. Later I learned that the belt 
> tesion was to high and the bearing was hard-steering. This results 
> during the operation of the twister stepping motor in a loss of steps. 
> Loss of steps or slipping has the same effect, the twister does not 
> turn to the expected angle. We solved this issue by exchanging the 
> bearing with a smooth running one and by a LONGER belt producing lower 
> tension and thereby lower friction in the bearings of the motor and 
> the sample holder.
>
> I don't know if this helps to solve your problem but eventually this 
> could help others. At least here in Munich it worked.
>
> Best regards
>
> Hartmann
>
> -- 
> Dr. H. Harz
> Ludwig-Maximilians-Universitt Mnchen
> Biozentrum
> AG Prof. Leonhardt
> Raum B02.059
> Grohaderner Strae 2
> 82152 Martinsried
> Germany
> Phone: +49(89)2180-74 259
> Fax: +49(89)218099-74 236
> Mail:harz at biz.uni-muenchen.de
>
>
> On 19.11.2014 18:42, Michael Redd wrote:
>> I am struggling with the twister motor belt slipping that others have 
>> mentioned.  I have seen the toothed belt used by Edgar's group in 
>> Aachen and would be much obliged if he described this in more detail 
>> so I could copy it.
>> -- 
>> Michael Redd

From gabriel.jones at florey.edu.au  Thu Jan 15 08:10:13 2015
From: gabriel.jones at florey.edu.au (Gabriel Davis Jones)
Date: Thu, 15 Jan 2015 14:10:13 +0000
Subject: [OpenSPIM] Best practices for using a different camera?
Message-ID: <005022868505164C94291D8DD2D8EBAA7415076C@000S-EX-MBX-QS4.unimelb.edu.au>

Hi All,

We are currently trying to use an Andor Neo camera in our OpenSPIM setup instead of the described Hamamatsu.
Is there some "best practices" advice anyone could give regarding how to go about using a different camera in the setup (preferably the Andor Neo) and how to get the FIJI/OpenSPIM package to cooperate with the camera?

Thank you,


Gabriel Davis Jones


Florey Institute for Neuroscience and Mental Health
Laboratory for Ion Channels and Human Diseases
Level 1 Kenneth Myer Building
Genetics Lane on Royal Parade
-------------- next part --------------
An HTML attachment was scrubbed...
URL: <http://openspim.org/pipermail/openspim/attachments/20150115/d92784ef/attachment-0002.html>

From guenther at mpi-cbg.de  Fri Jan 16 05:23:15 2015
From: guenther at mpi-cbg.de (=?UTF-8?Q?Ulrik_G=C3=BCnther?=)
Date: 16 Jan 2015 12:23:15 +0100
Subject: [OpenSPIM] Best practices for using a different camera?
In-Reply-To: <005022868505164C94291D8DD2D8EBAA7415076C@000S-EX-MBX-QS4.unimelb.edu.au>
References: <005022868505164C94291D8DD2D8EBAA7415076C@000S-EX-MBX-QS4.unimelb.edu.au>
Message-ID: <440928CF-DBFD-4F5C-BECD-2ADBF60CEF68@mpi-cbg.de>

  Hello Gabriel,


we are also using Andor Neo cameras and they work pretty great.


Currently, we are refactoring the OpenSPIM plugin, so it can be used with a normal installation of Fiji and MicroManager, so our special package is not needed anymore. I have a recent nightly build available, based on MicroManager 1.4.18, which you can find athttps://idisk-srv1.mpi-cbg.de/~gunther/OpenSPIM/mFiji.zip
The corresponding OpenSPIM plugin is available athttps://idisk-srv1.mpi-cbg.de/~gunther/OpenSPIM/SPIMacquisition.jar
and has to be put into the mmplugins/ directory. This version also works on 64bit machines.


With this version, you can just create your setup as usual, just select the Andor SDK3 as camera.


Please let me know if that worked for you :-)


cheers,


ulrik





Ulrik Gnther, Dipl.-Phys.
PhD Student
MOSAIC Group & Tomancak Lab,Center of Systems Biology Dresden
Max Planck Institute of Molecular Cell Biology and Genetics
Pfotenhauerstr. 108, D-01307 Dresden, Germany



E-Mail:guenther at mpi-cbg.de




> On Jan 15, 2015, at 3:10 PM, Gabriel Davis Jones <gabriel.jones at florey.edu.au> wrote:
> 
> 
> Hi All,
> 
> We are currently trying to use an Andor Neo camera in our OpenSPIM setup instead of the described Hamamatsu.
> Is there some "best practices" advice anyone could give regarding how to go about using a different camera in the setup (preferably the Andor Neo) and how to get the FIJI/OpenSPIM package to cooperate with the camera?
> 
> 
> Thank you,
>

From m.pawlowska at nencki.gov.pl  Fri Jan 16 05:33:38 2015
From: m.pawlowska at nencki.gov.pl (=?utf-8?B?TW9uaWthIFBhd8WCb3dza2E=?=)
Date: Fri, 16 Jan 2015 12:33:38 +0100
Subject: [OpenSPIM] OpenSPIM app 64bit and other issues
Message-ID: <op.xsjzqcn1ahhlbl@pc511-7cad.ibd>

Hi all,

I am new here, so first of all - big thanks to everybody for taking time
to help!

Now, to the topic. Are there any news regarding a possible 64bit version  
of the package? Or alternatively, an instruction that one can follow to  
install/build a 64bit version on one's own machine? For example by adding  
the 64bit micro-manager .dll libraries manually?

In the end I got the package running by using the ImageJ_win32 in  
compatibility mode. However, the solution Luke proposed in one of his  
emails - to put a java folder in the openspim.app folder - doesn't work  
for me and I was forced to change the JAVA_HOME option to use the 32bit  
java globally. Now I'm concerned that it will mess up other things. Do you  
have any experience with that?

Best regards,

-- 
Monika Pawowska
Nencki Institute
Laboratory of Neurobiology
3, Pasteur Street
02-093 Warsaw, Poland
phone: (+48) 22 5892 427



From guenther at mpi-cbg.de  Fri Jan 16 05:42:15 2015
From: guenther at mpi-cbg.de (=?UTF-8?Q?Ulrik_G=C3=BCnther?=)
Date: 16 Jan 2015 12:42:15 +0100
Subject: [OpenSPIM] OpenSPIM app 64bit and other issues
In-Reply-To: <op.xsjzqcn1ahhlbl@pc511-7cad.ibd>
References: <op.xsjzqcn1ahhlbl@pc511-7cad.ibd>
Message-ID: <25B9D7CD-486B-45E0-98FD-D5DE6518B2D7@mpi-cbg.de>

  Hello Monika,


were currently working on making OpenSPIM into a simple MicroManager plugin so the whole custom MicroManager package is not needed anymore.
This will also solve your 64bit troubles. For the moment, I can provide you with a 64bit build based on MicroManager 1.4.18, which you can find athttps://idisk-srv1.mpi-cbg.de/~gunther/OpenSPIM/mFiji.zip



Youll also need the OpenSPIM plugin, which you can find athttps://idisk-srv1.mpi-cbg.de/~gunther/OpenSPIM/SPIMacquisition.jar
- this has to be put in mmplugins/
Please also make sure you have the 1.8 version of the Java JRE installed.


Let me know if that worked for you :-)


cheers,


ulrik





Ulrik Gnther, Dipl.-Phys.
PhD Student
MOSAIC Group & Tomancak Lab,Center of Systems Biology Dresden
Max Planck Institute of Molecular Cell Biology and Genetics
Pfotenhauerstr. 108, D-01307 Dresden, Germany



E-Mail:guenther at mpi-cbg.de

CriticalError: plugins/Volume_Viewer-2.01.1-SNAPSHOT.jar
Multiple locally-modified versions of  
plugins/Volume_Viewer-2.01.1-SNAPSHOT.jar exist:  
C:\Users\MPAWLO~1\DOWNLO~1\mFiji\mFiji\plugins\Volume_Viewer.jar

Hi Hugo,
I have been using the multidimensional acquisition in MM as well for acquisition of multiple channels and found that it works well with the Picard twister, but I have to adjust the position of the twister motor with the openspim acquistion plugin. Maybe this was obvious to everyone else.  My Orca ER appears to be synced with my Stradus laser and my Vincent shutter (543 HeNe laser). I am sorry that  cannot advise you  concerning your timing problem.

Good luck
mike

From: Hugo Sderlund <hugo.soderlund at gmail.com<mailto:hugo.soderlund at gmail.com>>
Date: Friday, January 16, 2015 7:30 AM

Subject: OpenSpim
Resent-From: Michael Redd <michael.redd at hci.utah.edu<mailto:michael.redd at hci.utah.edu>>

Hi Michael,

I saw your message on the OpenSpim website about using two colors. We want to do the same thing. We have 488, 405 and 561 nm lasers installed and we are trying to use the multidimensional acquisition in MM (since there is no multi channel acquisition in OpenSpim) in order to acquire at least two channels for each z-stack. Unfortunately I cannot help you with your problem since we are not using the twister, only stepping in z-direction. But I was wondering if you have some advice for us.. We have noticed that the MultiDimensional acquisition is out of sync for the camera and the lasers, did you connect the camera with the lasers using TTL connection? If so, did you use the camera as master or slave in your connection? Does it require an arduino curcuit or similar?

Many questions, but any help would be very much appreciated. Thank you for your time.

Kind regards,

Hugo

From johannes.schindelin at gmx.de  Sat Jan 17 11:33:11 2015
From: johannes.schindelin at gmx.de (Johannes Schindelin)
Date: Sat, 17 Jan 2015 18:33:11 +0100
Subject: [OpenSPIM] rotational calibration
In-Reply-To: <D0DEEA30.21F3C%mredd@cores.utah.edu>
References: <D0DEEA30.21F3C%mredd@cores.utah.edu>
Message-ID: <03f116cdf4a4afe7dcc9e65e57088902@www.dscho.org>

Hi Michael,

On 2015-01-17 00:17, Michael Redd wrote:
> I am struggling with the rotational calibration tool. It doesn't
> appear to function at all on my machine (Windows 7 32bit). After
> calibrating pixel size, I can open up the rotational calibration
> window, but that is as far as I get. Pushing the"obtain next" button
> doesn't appear to do anything. Futhermore, I  can't find good
> instructions on  how to rotationally calibrate the Openspim. Any
> advice would be welcome.

Unfortunately, this is a part of the OpenSPIM software that was affected 
by a backwards-incompatible update in one of the libraries shipped with 
Fiji. I hope to find some time on Monday to prepare an updated OpenSPIM 
plugin that copes with that change, but in the meantime you could maybe 
verify that my suspicion is correct, by following the steps described in 
http://fiji.sc/Command-Line_Debugging to obtain the console output (if I 
am right, there should be a ClassNotFound or MethodNotFound exception in 
the log).

Ciao,
Johannes



From johannes.schindelin at gmx.de  Sat Jan 17 11:40:46 2015
From: johannes.schindelin at gmx.de (Johannes Schindelin)
Date: Sat, 17 Jan 2015 18:40:46 +0100
Subject: [OpenSPIM] two colors with Openspim plugin
In-Reply-To: <D0D19C9B.21995%mredd@cores.utah.edu>
References: <D0D19C9B.21995%mredd@cores.utah.edu>
Message-ID: <44fbb519ed4085d45e2867a5f90cabad@www.dscho.org>

Hi Michael,

On 2015-01-06 22:07, Michael Redd wrote:
> I have set up an Openspim microscope with a 488nm line and would like
> to add another laser. What is puzzling me is whether the Openspim
> plugin is capable of capturing two channels? I have added a 543nm gas
> laser and a shutter, but have been unable to set up channels in
> Openspim as one can easily do in micromanager. I can collect red and
> green channels in micromanager but cannot control the twister motor.
> Can anyone advise me?

You are correct: it should not be a big problem in the OpenSPIM software 
because Micro-Manager already supports multiple channels.

Having said that, it is an undertaking that requires Java programming 
skills and the OpenSPIM project has yet to attract more scientists with 
such skills to become stronger. Do you have such skills, or access to 
such a person? If so, I would try to find the time to identify the 
locations in the code that need changes.

Ciao,
Johannes

In any event I'd be happy to start working on this-or, I'm going to have to start working  on it soon!

From johannes.schindelin at gmx.de  Sun Jan 18 08:23:48 2015
From: johannes.schindelin at gmx.de (Johannes Schindelin)
Date: Sun, 18 Jan 2015 15:23:48 +0100
Subject: [OpenSPIM] two colors with Openspim plugin
In-Reply-To: <0154B08B-03D0-4128-9DE1-AEC388C1715F@iu.edu>
References: <D0D19C9B.21995%mredd@cores.utah.edu>,
	<44fbb519ed4085d45e2867a5f90cabad@www.dscho.org>
	<0154B08B-03D0-4128-9DE1-AEC388C1715F@iu.edu>
Message-ID: <00ab67f3aeaa18431aeeea12044681ec@www.dscho.org>

Hi Seth,

On 2015-01-17 19:48, Winfree, Seth wrote:

> We're putting together a five line OpenSPIM and one of my goals was to
> get multichannel/multi laser control in the OpenSPIM plugin.  I have a
> reasonable amount of Java experience-mostly imagej plugins.  I was
> planning on tackle this in the coming weeks as more parts for our
> microscope arrive.  I need to look under the hood of micromanager as
> well and look at the OpenSPIM source.  If only time there was more
> time.  In any event I'd be happy to start working on this-or, I'm
> going to have to start working  on it soon!

This is awesome news. Please keep in mind that I started migrating the 
OpenSPIM plugin for Micro-Manager into its own repository: 
https://github.com/openspim/SPIMAcquisition

It is now organized as a Maven project which means that you can simply 
import into your development environment of choice.

My original plan (with which I tasked a student who was working on the 
software at that time) was to get the plugin included in Micro-Manager 
proper, but unfortunately the plugin has already way too many 
dependencies that are only available in Fiji and not in Micro-Manager 
(and it would be unreasonable to ask the Micro-Manager developers to 
include them just for OpenSPIM).


And yes, if time was less of a concern, then we would already have

- a split between the parts of OpenSPIM that truly need libraries 
shipped only with Fiji and the parts that only need what Micro-Manager 
provides out of the box

- a way to test inside Eclipse, including mock devices including a 
twister

- regression tests

It would be really nice to have, but I simply do not have the time to 
make any of the above a reality.

All the better that you need to work at least on some part of the 
software :-) Please feel more than welcome to ask any question you have 
about the OpenSPIM or Micro-Manager source code; I will try to address 
as many as possible, after all: the more we work together and help each 
other, the better the OpenSPIM project will benefit every one of us.

Ciao,
Johannes

Seth/Johannes,

I've edited the OpenSPIM code to enable turning on/off and adjusting the power on multiple channels for a VersaLase.  It's not how I'd like it to work in the longterm (haven't had time to work on it), but I'd be more than happy to share what I've done. Gregory (Graham) Marquart

From beekayspim at gmail.com  Mon Jan 19 22:57:29 2015
From: beekayspim at gmail.com (Balki K)
Date: Tue, 20 Jan 2015 12:57:29 +0800
Subject: [OpenSPIM] SCAPE and SPIM
Message-ID: <CAG6WU3UbGug8Ww9Wpjaa3Stn5aedGHDxvNWnK78qZPPY6RRY4g@mail.gmail.com>

Dear All,

I am a new entrant into SPIM as well this forum.

I have been asked to explore building a mSPIM system for our institute. But
yesterday there was an update on a new type of system called SCAPE.

Please have a look at the online version of the publication in Nature
Photonics from Hillman's group in Columbia University, NY.

I have a clear understanding of SPIM system. But SCAPE is new to me. Is
there someone who is familiar with the two different systems that can
explain the pros & cons o SCAPE system?

Best Regards,
Balki
-------------- next part --------------

From johannes.schindelin at gmx.de  Tue Jan 20 01:50:20 2015
From: johannes.schindelin at gmx.de (Johannes Schindelin)
Date: Tue, 20 Jan 2015 08:50:20 +0100
Subject: [OpenSPIM] SCAPE and SPIM
In-Reply-To: <CAG6WU3UbGug8Ww9Wpjaa3Stn5aedGHDxvNWnK78qZPPY6RRY4g@mail.gmail.com>
References: <CAG6WU3UbGug8Ww9Wpjaa3Stn5aedGHDxvNWnK78qZPPY6RRY4g@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <0d2afa3c93b0c39744d8af536aa8298b@www.dscho.org>

Hi Balki,

On 2015-01-20 05:57, Balki K wrote:

> I am a new entrant into SPIM as well this forum.

Welcome! ;-)

> I have been asked to explore building a mSPIM system for our institute. 
> But
> yesterday there was an update on a new type of system called SCAPE.
> 
> Please have a look at the online version of the publication in Nature
> Photonics from Hillman's group in Columbia University, NY.

We are all busy, so it is a good practice to include a link if you 
already have one handy. I looked it up and I *think* you refer to this 
one?

http://www.nature.com/nphoton/journal/vaop/ncurrent/full/nphoton.2014.323.html

Unfortunately, I am not at a computer which can access the full text 
(and even more unfortunate: the authors did not upload preprints to 
arxiv nor bioRxiv) and you will understand that $32 is a bit much just 
to be able to analyze the technique for you ;-)

> I have a clear understanding of SPIM system. But SCAPE is new to me. Is
> there someone who is familiar with the two different systems that can
> explain the pros & cons o SCAPE system?

Please keep in mind that I bring the software engineering expertise to 
the OpenSPIM project in our lab, not the optics expertise (you probably 
have much more knowledge of optics, given that you are tasked to build a 
microscope). And please keep in mind that I form the following 
understanding only from reading the abstract of the article, supported 
only by the figure at 
http://www.nature.com/nphoton/journal/vaop/ncurrent/fig_tab/nphoton.2014.323_F1.html.

With those caveats in mind, my interpretation is that their microscope 
uses a scanning mirror (or cantilever) to move the light sheet through 
the specimen, and that the light sheet is not perpendicular to the 
acquisition axis but at an oblique angle.

The OpenSPIM setup we published uses a stage to move the specimen 
instead of the light sheet (which means that the optical sections are 
parallel, unlike the sections obtained by rotating the light sheet with 
a cantilever  even if they are *almost* parallel in practice). Further, 
in the OpenSPIM setup, the images have uniform pixel spacings because 
the light sheet is perpendicular to the acquisition axis, while the 
pixel spacings in images acquired by the SCAPE microscope differ not 
only depending on the current angle of the light sheet but also on the 
exact coordinate on the image plane.

The major difference, therefore, appears that the SCAPE microscope can 
be much faster (because it moves the light sheet much faster), at the 
expense of requiring a sophisticated reconstruction algorithm because of 
the non-uniform pixel spacings (read: point spread functions).

It would be really cool if you could adapt the OpenSPIM setup to support 
SCAPE microscopy; You should make sure that you have access to a gifted 
mathematician with intermediate programming skills to implement the 
image reconstruction (read: the all-too-common half-hearted Matlab 
snippet won't do at all).

Looking forward to your progress!
Johannes

Hi Gregory,

On 2015-01-20 00:37, Marquart, Gregory (NIH/NICHD) [F] wrote:

> I've edited the OpenSPIM code to enable turning on/off and adjusting
> the power on multiple channels for a VersaLase.  It's not how I'd like
> it to work in the longterm (haven't had time to work on it), but I'd
> be more than happy to share what I've done.  Possibly the best would
> be to post my modified repository, otherwise I could send you the
> code, etc.  Let me know your preference.

The easiest for me would be a GitHub Pull Request [*1*], but if you are 
uncomfortable with such fantsy-pantsy newfangled techniques, posting the 
modified repository would do quite nicely (it would take a little longer 
to get included in the latter case, unfortunately, because I will be 
busy with a hackathon for a week starting tomorrow, and the OpenSPIM 
software developer community is still nascent).

Thank you!
Johannes

Footnote *1*: https://help.github.com/articles/creating-a-pull-request/

From: Ulrik Gnther [guenther at mpi-cbg.de]
Sent: 16 January 2015 22:23
To: Gabriel Davis Jones
Cc: openspim at openspim.org
Subject: Re: [OpenSPIM] Best practices for using a different camera?

Hello Gabriel,

we are also using Andor Neo cameras and they work pretty great.

Currently, we are refactoring the OpenSPIM plugin, so it can be used with a normal installation of Fiji and MicroManager, so our special package is not needed anymore. I have a recent nightly build available, based on MicroManager 1.4.18, which you can find at https://idisk-srv1.mpi-cbg.de/~gunther/OpenSPIM/mFiji.zip The corresponding OpenSPIM plugin is available at https://idisk-srv1.mpi-cbg.de/~gunther/OpenSPIM/SPIMacquisition.jar and has to be put into the mmplugins/ directory. This version also works on 64bit machines.

With this version, you can just create your setup as usual, just select the Andor SDK3 as camera.

Please let me know if that worked for you :-)

cheers,

ulrik


-
Ulrik Gnther, Dipl.-Phys.
PhD Student
MOSAIC Group & Tomancak Lab, Center of Systems Biology Dresden
Max Planck Institute of Molecular Cell Biology and Genetics
Pfotenhauerstr. 108, D-01307 Dresden, Germany

E-Mail: guenther at mpi-cbg.de

On Jan 15, 2015, at 3:10 PM, Gabriel Davis Jones <gabriel.jones at florey.edu.au> wrote:

Hi All,

We are currently trying to use an Andor Neo camera in our OpenSPIM setup instead of the described Hamamatsu.
Is there some "best practices" advice anyone could give regarding how to go about using a different camera in the setup (preferably the Andor Neo) and how to get the FIJI/OpenSPIM package to cooperate with the camera?

Thank you,


Gabriel Davis Jones


Florey Institute for Neuroscience and Mental Health
Laboratory for Ion Channels and Human Diseases
Level 1 Kenneth Myer Building
Genetics Lane on Royal Parade

From gabriel.jones at florey.edu.au  Thu Jan 22 01:38:28 2015
From: gabriel.jones at florey.edu.au (Gabriel Davis Jones)
Date: Thu, 22 Jan 2015 07:38:28 +0000
Subject: [OpenSPIM] Best practices for using a different camera?
In-Reply-To: <440928CF-DBFD-4F5C-BECD-2ADBF60CEF68@mpi-cbg.de>
References: <005022868505164C94291D8DD2D8EBAA7415076C@000S-EX-MBX-QS4.unimelb.edu.au>,
	<440928CF-DBFD-4F5C-BECD-2ADBF60CEF68@mpi-cbg.de>
Message-ID: <005022868505164C94291D8DD2D8EBAA7415610D@000S-EX-MBX-QS4.unimelb.edu.au>

Hi All,

The issue was solved by reinstalling the drivers to the mFiji package using the following Andor package: http://www.andor.com/ftp/14544/AndorDriverPack3Setup-3.7.30010.0.ziphttp://www.andor.com/ftp/14544/AndorDriverPack3Setup-3.7.30010.0.zip
When prompted for the install location, just change it to the mFiji folder.

Thanks Ulrik for all the help!


Kind regards,

Gabriel Davis Jones

Laboratory for Ion Channels and Human Diseases
Level 1 Kenneth Myer Building
Genetics Lane on Royal Parade

From m.pawlowska at nencki.gov.pl  Thu Jan 22 04:54:42 2015
From: m.pawlowska at nencki.gov.pl (=?utf-8?B?TW9uaWthIFBhd8WCb3dza2E=?=)
Date: Thu, 22 Jan 2015 11:54:42 +0100
Subject: [OpenSPIM] Picard hi-res stage
Message-ID: <op.xsu1xghwahhlbl@pc511-7cad.ibd>

Hi,

thanks to the help of Ulrik I was able to install and run the OpenSPIM  
plugin in my lab. When testing the Picard stage, I noticed following  
issues:

-integer range issue: I have bought the new Hi-Res Picard stage which can  
do 45 000 steps. However, in the OpenSPIM plugin I can only do 32 767  
steps (16bit integer range if I'm not wrong)

-display issue: the GUI of the plugin, I mean the window with the sliders  
for the stage, only shows range up to 9000 um, but the new Hi-res stage  
can do 12000 um. How can this be changed?

I think the first issue is already in the MManager driver for the Picard,  
the second in the java OpenSPIM plugin. Does somebody have the solution  
already or could gave me a hint what to do?

Best regards,

-- 
Monika Pawowska
Nencki Institute
Laboratory of Neurobiology
3, Pasteur Street
02-093 Warsaw, Poland

Hello Gabriel,

we are also using Andor Neo cameras and they work pretty great.

Currently, we are refactoring the OpenSPIM plugin, so it can be used with a normal installation of Fiji and MicroManager, so our special package is not needed anymore. I have a recent nightly build available, based on MicroManager 1.4.18, which you can find at https://idisk-srv1.mpi-cbg.de/~gunther/OpenSPIM/mFiji.zip The corresponding OpenSPIM plugin is available at https://idisk-srv1.mpi-cbg.de/~gunther/OpenSPIM/SPIMacquisition.jar and has to be put into the mmplugins/ directory. This version also works on 64bit machines.

With this version, you can just create your setup as usual, just select the Andor SDK3 as camera.

Please let me know if that worked for you :-)

cheers,

ulrik

Hi Ulrik,

On 2015-01-22 14:35, Ulrik Gnther wrote:

> * can we use Travis CI or something to check whether the plugin
> builds/works with M and Fiji nightlies?

We could (for lurkers, Ulrik speaks about a server dedicated to building 
and testing the software, say, every night). There is a Jenkins CI at 
http://jenkins.imagej.net/ that Fiji and ImageJ use. We could easily set 
something up there.

But we do not have any regression tests; therefore, the usefulness of 
such a continuous integration is not yet large enough to merit the huge 
amount of work to get the continuous integration up and running *and* to 
keep it running.

> * Id also integrate support for the high precision stage Monika is
> using (see her other mail on the list)

Sure! I'll be glad to review and merge any Pull Request you throw my 
way.

Ciao,
Johannes
